questions.clue: This winged horse was born from the blood of Medusa and is often associated with the hero Bellerophon.
Known for their riddles, these half-woman, half-lion creatures are found in Greek mythology, famously terrorizing the city of Thebes.
This Chinese dragon-like creature is associated with the discovery of the character for writing and is said to appear during times of prosperity.
Originating from Norse mythology, these serpentine sea monsters encircle the world and are known as Midgard Serpents.
This fire-breathing creature from Slavic folklore is often depicted as a multi-headed dragon-like being and is a formidable foe for heroes.
For 200 points: This physicist developed the famous uncertainty principle, stating limitations on precisely measuring certain pairs of physical properties.
For 400 points: In quantum mechanics, this principle states that every particle or quantum entity may be partly described in terms not only of particles, but also of waves.
For 600 points: This theory proposed by Hugh Everett III suggests that all possible outcomes of quantum measurements are physically realized in some 'world' or universe.
For 800 points: In quantum mechanics, this mathematical tool is used to predict the future behavior of a quantum system.
For 1000 points: This phenomenon, demonstrated in the famous double-slit experiment, illustrates the bizarre wave nature of particles and the importance of the observer.

categories.name: Art Movements That Shook the World

questions.clue: This 19th-century art movement began in France and is known for its small, visible brush strokes and emphasis on light.
Characterized by its embrace of geometric forms and cubes, this movement was pioneered by Picasso and Braque.
Emerging in the early 20th century, this art movement expressed the dissatisfaction with conventional forms and was led by artists like Duchamp.
This post-World War II movement, originating in New York, is noted for its use of bold colors and sudden bursts of color or pigment.
Founded by André Breton, this movement sought to resolve the previously contradictory conditions of dream and reality into an absolute reality, a super-reality.

categories.name: Around the World in Unusual Foods

questions.clue: This insect larva, commonly consumed in Mexico, is often used to flavor mezcal.
Considered a delicacy in Scotland, this dish is made by boiling a sheep's stomach filled with offal.
In Iceland, this sharks' rotting and fermented version is called 'hákarl'.
A street food in the Philippines, this fertilized duck egg with a partially developed embryo is known as what?
Popular in Sardinia, this cheese contains live insect larvae and is considered an illegal delicacy in some places.
This novel begins, 'It was the best of times, it was the worst of times.'
questions.answer: What is A Tale of Two Cities?

questions.clue: Identify the novel with the line, 'Call me Ishmael.'
'All happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.' is the opening line of this Russian classic.
This dystopian novel starts with, 'It was a bright cold day in April, and the clocks were striking thirteen.'
Name the novel that opens with, 'In our family, there was no clear line between religion and fly fishing.'
questions.answer: What is A River Runs Through It?

final.clue: First published in 1922, this novel follows the life of Stephen Dedalus & features a stream-of-consciousness style.
